content.description:
Z-Cracks is on the Northeast side of King of the Throne.  It is aptly named, as the crack forms some form of a Z.  The climb is only about 50 feet in length.  Jam up and slightly left, then up a steep right facing dihedral, then exit left in a bulging hand crack (the crux).  After pulling the hand crack, set an anchor from large cams.

There is a set of fixed anchors which rap off the opposite side of the formation.  Only one rope needed.
content.protection: Standard rack - mainly hand sized pieces.  Bigger stuff needed for an anchor (3 or 3.5 - 5 camalots).

content.description: Either wedge yourself in the chimney and have some physical fun or pinch the arete to the right. either way, eventually reach a roof with great hand jams and pull it.
content.protection: Up to a #2 camalot. Lots of small stuff for the lower corner. Descend via a tree w/ slings and rap rings.
content.location: The route is just left of the Snakes and Ladders face. The obvious roof w/ a thin hand crack.

content.description: to the right of z-cracks and Stan's roof. Start in the  cool finger crack dike, and stem up to a standard City runout finish, but on positive patina climbing.  Gear appears right when you start really wanting it in the horizontals.  from  the last gear, you can go right or left...left is a touch steeper, but bigger jugs. Fun route!
content.protection: Standard free rack (smaller cams for upper face)
content.location: East side of King on the throne,  start in the alcove with the obvious dike

content.description: A unique bouldery start using lots of opposition will get you to the cheese (jugs).  Once in the cheese you are trapped (it's much easier to continue up than to climb back down).  Originally free soloed.  Can be lead with gear or considered a V3 high-ball boulder problem.  Descend the 'King On the Throne' down-climb 30 feet climbers left of the route or rappel off anchors on the other side of the rock.
content.protection: Trad gear or free solo on easy and enjoyable terrain once past the initial crux.
content.location: Approximately 15 feet left of the route 'Jug World'.  Look for a blank section of rock with a series of white quartz dikes (see photo for start).

content.description:
Jug World is on the Northeast side of King of the Throne.  It is the farthest continous crack system on the left side of the face.  The climb is only about 30-40 feet in length.  Jug haul your way up the face holds and sharp crack with the crux getting off the ground.  After gaining the ridge, traverse right to a horizontal crack (quite a ways) where an anchor can be set.

There is a set of fixed anchors which rap off the opposite side of the formation.  Only one rope needed.
content.protection: Standard rack - I placed from .75 camalot up to 3 camalot.  There is no anchor, but a distant crack that can eat up #3 and #3.5 camalots.
